7. Urge in any communication to daily newspaper publishers and
editors that they, wherever possible, assign a specific reporter, or
channel all highway safety material through one reporter, to develop a
knowledgeable expert in this highly complex undertaking#
8. Urge the daily newspapers to organize at the local level the
efforts of substantial highway safety groups, with strong news and
editorial page support.
Respectfully submitted, W.S.LAMPE, Chairman
Weekly Newspaper Committee
The Weekly Newspaper Committee of the Media Group recommends the
following suggestions as to the part weekly newspapers can play in proÂ¬
moting the Crusade for Safety:
1. Sponsor all possible movements to promote and encourage
highway safety and make a success of the "Crusade for Safety".
2. Editorialize the local accident, with emphasis on the cause.
3. Give wide publicity to local organizations, endorsing their
safety movements and encouraging them in their work.
U. Encourage enactment of legislation to provide State aid for
training small city police officers, thereby helping to alleviate the
incompetence now noted in so many small villages.
5. Encourage schools and youth organizations to promote student
highway safety councils to help youthful drivers get off to a good start
in driver courtesy and practice.
6. Ask their respective State Legislatures to bring the Highway
Patrol up to full strength, as advocated by the National Safety Council.
7. Explore the idea of promoting the setting up of Citizens
Reporting Committees in their towns, with names kept confidential.
8. Suggest that the States use psychiatry and other scientific
means to eliminate mentally unfit drivers.
9. Unite in a one-week test of public cooperation in a "Stay-
Alive Week," encouraging public cooperation and gauging the sincerity of
the public in this all-important safety work.
